I am able to use my email and password to correctly login to the website and everything is fine. However, I input my same credentials on this app and I get an error that says either the username or password is incorrect, which doesn’t make sense.

I would love to be able to use the app and continue studying for certifications while I’m not at my PC, but cannot do so at the moment because of this issue.

As for LetsDefend itself, I am in love with this style of learning and how it’s all set up. It’s very structured and the quizzes at the end make sure you understand everything before you move on to a new module. At least for the PC version, there are also labs that you can connect to that allow you to interact with the learning material even further, which makes everything so much smoother for overall comprehension. You receive badges at the end of each major module and for the VIP version, you get a certificate for each completed course that you can show to employers.

I highly recommend the website (can’t really say the app for now) for anyone looking to get into Cybersecurity.

Thanks and Good Luck!

The concept of the game is well-thought-out and original, but there are many execution issues. The writing is spelled out in jumbled, typo-ridden English. There are ten stages a “level,” in addition to multiple tutorials, and progress is not saved at any point in the chapter. The graphics are fuzzy and glitchy. With an additional year spent developing this game, it could have been excellent, but at present, it reads as a prototype.

Usually when I’ve played other games from these devs I rarely see many bugs and issues, but with this one I do. Now don’t get me wrong this is a good game and i enjoyed it but the bugs ruin it a bit.

The Random Crashes Problem:
For example there are idk.. I’ll estimate around 3-6 buttons that crash ur game when pressed making some features completely unusable. 

The Series Problem:
And when you make a series well… at first it works fine but after a bit u realize it’s saying ur releasing WAY more episodes than u actually are. Now that’s fine I suppose just a issue with the way it calculates my episodes. But there is another problem, when u make a second series and make a episode in that series it for some reason bugs out and says it’s in both series?!?! Like for example both ur first series and ur second series will show the exact same stats.

The YouView Problem:
Well it’s not rlly a problem, the devs were just a bit lazy when making this part. I assume they used part of the same code from their music sim game in here. Like for example when u click on smth u uploaded the top comment will say smth either abt the non existent music video or how well the artist did, and as you can clearly tell this is a game about making a podcast not music.

The GameCenter LeaderBoard Glitch:
It doesn’t actually show accurate stats. Like for example I have around 11.5k active paid subs on my play thru and yet when u check the leader board I’m somehow only at 230?!?! And this also goes for the money leaderboard I literally have 133m cash and yet it says I only have 6.1m.

If Ur Still Reading This:
I want to say that this game has just recently came out, maybe 1-3 days before this review and there is clear room for improvement with further updates.

My Review On This Game:
it’s a decently fun game and I enjoyed myself however it does seem like very rushed/lazy work from the devs and I’m honestly wondering if they even tested out there game once before releasing it. Because I honestly don’t understand how they could’ve tested out the game and not known of these issues.

I used up the initial credits (about $10) doing tasks that could have been accomplished in Claude in few-shot prompts. $40/mo for ten-ish tasks isn’t worth it and $200/mo is silly. They have examples in their documentation that tackle complex multi-domain research. They are rated at like 200 tokens but I’ll ask for simple things and it’ll chew up 400 credits providing me a list of local advertising avenues.  

I’ll keep my account open but I’m going to circle back in 6 months to 1 year to see if they figured out the money situation. If it’s still like this I’ll have appreciated it as a novel tech foundation that’ll be iterated on by someone who can engineer a way to use tokens more efficiently.

I don’t want to come across as mean or rude, but what is interpreted as negative feedback is often read in a tone that is exactly that, so please know that this is not my intention and I am providing honest feedback in the hopes that you take it to heart and better your product so that you are as successful as possible.                                  1. The camera being attached to an avatar was a terrible, yet easily correctable mistake. I, the viewer, should have full control of where I’m looking. If the virtual camera needs to move, it should be on rails and not jerking all over the place. Basically, don’t move the camera unless it’s absolutely necessary. I can understand that this can be a conundrum for certain scenes, like when she is falling, but this medium requires consideration and sacrifice to attract and keep the widest audience. Better to take that out of your story than to alienate an audience that doesn’t fair well with a camera that goes all over the place. 
2. When using AirPods for audio, the audio is terribly delayed. I did not try without. 
3. The last scene where you’re in a bar and the main character is a bit seductive in a slinky black dress, all whispering that she never wanted me to let go or whatever… yeah we don’t need that in a “Pixar-style experience”. I know some people enjoy sexualizing cartoons, but again - think about the audience and not wanting to alienate people. 
4. I have no idea what this even is. Since you’re developing what is basically a movie that the audience is a participant in, then you should’ve done more of a story trailer that tells me about this character, the world… why we are hanging out with this character and what their motivation is. Instead, I got what feels like a college game design project that you got a good grade on and didn’t want to go to waste after you graduated. It’s a random, nonsensical experience that has no rhyme or reason. You mention Pixar, so maybe go watch some trailers, then redo this whole thing like an immersive movie trailer rather than what it currently is. 
5. I also wanted to mention that when I first launched the app, my surroundings dimmed and I got an Apple logo, but not the VP Apple logo. It looked more like you added it as a loading icon or something, but IDK. Anyways, I was unable to force quit or do anything, so I had to restart. Thereafter when I launched the app the audio wouldn’t work and after showing the studio logo it would just go back to the “tap to start” screen over and over until I force quit the app and relaunched. 
6. Good on you for taking the time to learn and grow as a creative individual. Keep at it!

Dear Audiomodern developers, my review is more about expressing or spreading my discontent with you. I just realized that this time, my criticism and disappointment aren't going to the App Store. I wanted to buy PlayBeat 3, and strangely enough, it was only compatible with a higher version of iOS than the one I have, so I couldn't get used to it. And now you're releasing the same app, PlayBeat 4, which is superior to the previous version and is compatible with my device. You're definitely being very mean and shameless. As a consumer, I'm speaking out against these outrageous marketing strategies. I don't see the difference between charging a direct price for purchase and offering it for free, installing it, and then having to pay to unlock its most important and functional parts. And thank goodness you don't have that other absurd subscription strategy, which is a real rip-off. I don't understand why there are people who pay monthly or yearly for something they already bought. In conclusion, I've realized that you, as developers, program apps to work on your chosen versions of iOS. You've already demonstrated this with this bad trick: PlayBeat 3 iOS v. 13 or higher, and now PlayBeat 4, compatible with iOS lower than v. 13, free, with a fee for general unlocking. Your apps are great, but your marketing strategies leave much to be desired. I want you to understand my dissatisfaction as a consumer.

等了这么久，结果就给我整出这么个玩意？？？
本以为是放置养成，结果是高强度手操，一堆反人类的设计搞得跟996加班一样，整天盯着屏幕点点点，连个自动优化都没有。要不是我之前玩过作者的所有游戏，对这个新作还有点期待，我绝对不会忍这么久才来评论。

首先，这游戏已经开了氪金通道，不是完全免费的，那为什么优化就可以不管了？玩家天天反馈问题，一遍遍说UI反人类、操作过于繁琐、数值策划离谱，结果呢？策划团队直接选择性失明，装死不改。不想优化可以直说吗？这样大家也不会天天在评论区苦苦哀求。都做了氪金通道了，玩家的反馈就一点都不重要了吗？

炼丹系统也是离谱至极，批量炼丹都不行？ 每次点到手抽筋，不是每个玩家都能用连点器，你是想逼着大家去外接脚本才能玩得下去？更别说丹方药材的熟练度，每次炼丹都要重新摸索，完全不继承，真当玩家的时间是无限的吗？ 这也就算了，结果连最基础的玩法优化都不肯做，每次玩都像在重复劳动，完全没有养成的乐趣，纯粹是疲劳轰炸。

更气人的是，这游戏的交互体验根本不如作者之前的作品，像是在故意给老玩家找不痛快。商城里连基本的分类都没有，随便翻个材料都要眼花，界面割裂得仿佛还是上个世纪的网页游戏，哪怕是最基础的批量管理功能也没有，优化玩法就这么难吗？

最让我无法理解的是，这么多人联合上书请求整改，作者就是不改，死活不回应，到底是装听不见，还是根本就不在乎？

就算是一个人做的游戏，这也完全不影响它的破烂！ 作者到底在执拗什么？玩家提出的问题每个都合理，稍微花点时间优化一下，难道真的比逼走一批又一批忠实玩家更难？

——总结一下：想玩这游戏，你得有时间，有耐心，有连点器，还要愿意接受策划的无视和冷漠。如果你缺其中一项，劝你趁早跑路，别浪费时间。

Nice polished UI, especially from an indie developer. That said, this is a very limited application. Little tangible value regardless of marketing.

3) Zero details on integration with other software such as Quicken, Moneydance etc.

Personally, no need for budgeting or subscription tracking.

Yes, the app intentionally tries to bridge the gap of live connections with receipts, email and such. But so what? Even if it worked well the solution falls short of what finance tracking requires.

If these features suit your needs, 1) G*d bless you for simplified finance life and 2)  this app does the same as many that came before it, yet charges a great deal more. You can find similar for less.

Pros
- 6 jobs to choose between with plenty to unlock. Learn skills, buffs and skill slots. Skills belong to a category and can be equipped by any job that has a skill slot of the same category once unlocked.  
- 15 stat categories which is a lot for most. 
- 6 equipment slots, gear can have up to 3 RNG enchantments on it plus main stat (maybe more with progression). Gear is not job restricted. 

Cons
- Needs PSAs. 
- Poor inventory management. I could use maybe 5+ pre-sets to quickly change gear as right now it’s very tedious switching between offensive gear, xp gear, item drop gear and some jobs that need specific stats. Delete all items with zero enchantment would be greatly appreciated as well. 
- skills aren’t explained well. 
- Jobs tend to start with their drawbacks and you have to invest a lot of time or boost to find out if they are even good at all. E.I. Blind samurai job starting with -100% hit chance is way to rough for only a tier 2 job as it’s not possible balance that high of a debuff that soon in the game. 
- jobs should have buff slots as well similar to skill slots. 
- enchantments should include attack as well as more offensive stats to balance out all the defensive stats. 
- it doesn’t seem to have a huge focus on speed consider it’s the name of the game. Would be cool to see more content with this in mind.

Dear Developer, I wish you all the success, and regret that no one may have told you these truths I am about to mention, in hopes of your overall improvements. Nothing I am about to mention is intended in any way to be discouraging personal attacks, but sincere feedback:

Have you played “Armored Core6?” That is what a realistic ‘graphene’ future mech game should be. But this Exoloper game is making me pull my hair out. Crash at tutorial startup. Will not load tutorials second boot up, then tutorial is permanently gone. 1 stars is too much for this game. Worst mech game I ever seen, but why?…I list ten reasons, with the last being most scientific, and if you can skip to 10, that one would still be the straw that broke the camel’s back.

1-Slow servo mech, not even “metal-gear-solid-rex” like. Mechs are wrongfully envisioned by grandpa to be trope slow bulldozers.(proof in reason 10 But I digress…)

2-Worst than mech warrior1. -Objectives blown up-blows up entire map, killing all players, what is the point then?

3 -Small reason, Nukes are placed on the ground instead of fired so its suicide. (The blast radius red indicator does not match actual damage radius by hundredfold?)

4-Worst clunkiest controls I ever seen. You are forced to move at a paddle instead of instant control response like “w,a,s,d,” or right left foward back, or two way directional joystick, and x,y,z aim. 50% of screen cuts off.

5-Small reason, Did I also mention, forgive me for saying, the mechs shape are so ugly and poorly designed a child could draw a better humpdy dumpty potato with tiny sticks for legs?! Dwarf walker, short legs alone are obsolete. Use your imagination. But this can be worked on…

6- Big reason, The audio is choppy and grinding things on the ground is like scratching chalk board cringe. (I think I have a headache).

7 - Big reason, The screen is half covered by a blop of dark plates? So your play screen is reduced to 50%. (Tunnel vision will increase motion sickness).

8-There are no dodging mechanics chaf flares or defensive mechanics of stealth or jets or anything. (Impairs users hand eye co ordination).

9-🏆 I add one positive thing here: great focus on gameplay and less on textures and vain things. (Many new games nowadays, focus too much on graphics, they forget games are to be interactive, and not handholding movies).

10-⚠️Most importantly- not generous with loadouts, the weight limit is unreal: have you heard of “flash graphene?” It is a dirt cheap polymer carbon8 material in real life that is 900x stronger than steel and 200x lighter, allowing future tanks to be the weight of a small van. Pros:  
- Aesthetic Appeal: The interface is clean, modern, and visually pleasing—a standout for users who prioritize design.  
- Privacy Focus: Explicitly positions itself as a secure alternative to data-heavy keyboards like Gboard, which is a major plus for privacy-conscious users.  

Cons:  
- Compatibility Issues: Fails to work in apps critical for international communication, travel planning, and shopping, limiting its use for global connections.  
- Performance Lag: Feels sluggish even on an iPhone 16 Pro Max, causing frequent typos and forcing me to type slower than usual.  
- Missing Standard Features:  
  * No swipe/gesture typing, a staple on both the default iPhone keyboard and competitors like Gboard (despite their lack of privacy focus).  
  * No space-bar text scrolling, making editing cumbersome.  
  * Caps Lock Design: Requires double-tapping for caps lock instead of a single-character shift key, which feels unintuitive.  
  * No auto-capitalization for sentences, leading to manual fixes and slower typing.  
- Translation Limitations: While marketed as a Gboard replacement for translations, the lack of core features (e.g., swipe typing, auto-caps) undermines its practicality.  

Conclusion:  
This keyboard has clear potential thanks to its sleek design and privacy-first approach. However, it struggles with performance lag, app compatibility, and missing features that users expect in 2024. Prioritizing speed optimizations, adding swipe typing/auto-caps, and refining the shift key logic would elevate it significantly. For privacy-focused users willing to sacrifice convenience today, it’s a decent option—but with updates, it could become a top-tier choice.

Ubisoft Paris developed a phenomenal game. They've nailed the "easy to learn, hard to master," strategy dynamic. Characters and abilities are diverse, and true to the marketing: no two games are the same. 

Unfortunately, Ubisoft does not trust the gameplay to retain players and generate revenue. Unlike League of Legends or, more recently, Marvel Rivals; Ubisoft has chosen to lock stats and abilities behind in-game currencies. The currencies can be earned slowly by playing, or paid for. Cosmetics can be paid for as well.

It's a common mobile game tactic, and it's typically required for retention in games that are compensating for a lackluster gameplay loop. 

In BUMP's case, I think it's actually going to slash retention. This game is designed to attract MOBA enthusiasts more than RPG players, and MOBA players hate competitive inconsistencies more than anything.

Revenue is required. But my hope for Bump! is that they trust the gameplay and follow in LoL's footsteps. 

To make it 5 Stars:

Make the roster expensive; but when you unlock a character, there's no level-up. Players all start with the same 6 characters, and then there's a weekly rotation of "free" characters. Expand on the lore and design cool cosmetics, people will pay for them. Let the gameplay retain players, and trust that an obsessed player base will be happily monetized.

Overall, it was a decent experience, but not worth the price due to lack of balance, unclear progression, and lack of help information.

Positives: The game looks great; colorful with a unique art style. 
Controls are okay, and it’s easy to clean up a mistake. 
Gameplay loop is really fun (until it isn’t).
Negatives: The game timing ruins the entire experience. There is some mechanic which makes the game go from building to fighting. Triggering that mechanic is based on ‘sound’, but the game doesn’t define what increases sound. Additionally, there are character types to add to help your village, like a chef, but adding in these units excessively increases the trigger. Adding even 1 reduces your time to breed new settlers. If you add more than 2 special units, the trigger goes off and the fight starts. Since these units are your fighters, you can never actually have enough plus they abandon their primary job to fight. Each battle just becomes a hope that your settlers can kill the enemy before it kills them. 

Additionally, progression is non-existent. There are upgrades you can get, but these are randomly unlocked each run. Your goal is to get settlers to support upgrades and defeat the enemy on each island to then repair your boat. You go to a new island and start over. After a few islands, the credits role. If you lose all your settlers, you just  go to a new island with no consequences & hope you win the ‘base race’. 

There seems to be a lot of variety in the game, but due to the lack of balance and unclear progression, there becomes 1 single build pathway you must take to have a chance. Lots of promise fumbled by unrefined execution.

I’ve spent a good amount of time playing this game — even dropped some money on it — and honestly, it’s got potential. Yeah, there are bots here and there in matchmaking, but I get it, the game’s still new.

That said, there are a few things I really think could make it better. First off, for a game that’s all about collecting awesome loot, it’s kind of a bummer that none of the gear shows up on your character. Like, I’d love to actually see the helmets, gloves, boots, and chest pieces I’m equipping. Right now, your character just has the default look no matter what. In 2025, that’s just not cutting it — especially when other, lower-budget games are doing this already.

Also, since co-op is a big part of the game, it’d be awesome to have some weapons or items that actually work together. Imagine if there was an electricity item that could connect between two players’ drops, or fire grenades that could combine effects — stuff like that would make teamwork way more fun and rewarding.

Overall, I like where this is going, but there’s definitely room for some cool upgrades.

I’ve been following it since it was announced, and I was so happy that it came out, but the state it came out in should be a beta at best. It feels like there’s nothing to do, even if there is, and it just dumps you into the app with very little tutorials. I’m not asking for handholding, but I’ve been waiting years and I’m now dumped into an app with honestly annoying music and controls that don’t give feedback when pressed. I chose Dutch, which they said is incomplete, so maybe a bit of this is on me, but as far as I’m given, there are flashcards that do nothing for me, a matching bomb game, and a matching game where you type things out even if you haven’t seen these words before. There isn’t even the main mode open, which seems like something that should have been done first for every language. The animations are cute, but it’s stiff and doesn’t feel high quality for the time I spent waiting. And as I said before, the music is really annoying. It just plays in repeat the whole time. And pressing anything gives like no feed back in visuals or audio. It honestly makes me really sad since I looked up to the maker, personally wanting to be a polyglot and sharing their condition, but to receive the app in this state shattered my rise colored glasses a bit.
This app has potential, but it’s not ready for the public. The maker is a language learner, not an app programmer. I get he got help, but for the hype he made, he should have given this more time or hired better people. Just stick to Duolingo until this all has time to actually be made usable.

Not a fan of this game.

I get that significant cuts to the challenging content had to be made to do this 3d port, but both the final boss and the 4 optional superbosses are way too easy. I dropped Lunar Bahamut in 3 hits. Then I had nothing to use the reward on except an extremely weak final boss. 

I read about all these optional challenge dungeons in the 2d version that were cut from the 3d port, and that the original final dungeon was much bigger and contained way more bosses. So I was pretty disappointed to only find 4 optional bosses, no bonus dungeons, and a final boss that I was able to one shot. 

These are just criticisms of the 3d port. The story is incredible. FF4 was the first RPG I ever played as a child and I’ve replayed it throughout my life. Finally playing the sequel at 38 was very satisfying and nostalgic. The story did an excellent job of developing beloved characters even further and bringing an extremely cool dark sci-fi twist to all the well worn but well executed fantasy tropes inherent to FF4. I may just have to play the 2d version on an emulator to get the full experience. This is a fun playthrough, but don’t expect too much of a challenge.

The game opens with a strong set of visuals and story premise. The tutorial feels well integrated, but I was left wondering what this astronaut’s deal was. We don’t know where she was going or why. We have an objective-escape the planet- but I find it unusual that the astronaut’s first goal isn’t to get in touch with someone else about her crash- does she have no oversight? That would be fine for a solo explorer, except for a small tidbit of info dropped at the very end of the game. It feels like things just don’t add up.

The environments are very well realized for this type of adventure game, and very thoughtful in their functionality for mobile. I do wish the various creatures were better realized; at first, I felt like they must “actually” look like that on this strange planet. However, another reveal later in the game defies this idea and highlights that these silhouetted creatures definitely aren’t well thought out in terms of design.

The puzzles were reasonable; for better or worse, the days of sitting stuck on a tough puzzler for weeks to months without a walkthrough or guide are gone. Mobile does tend to make puzzling a little less robust- the types of puzzles begin to feel a bit repetitive by the end of the game. That said, they did feel well integrated into the world that was crafted.

However, the character lines around the puzzles really cheapens the experience. I don’t want to feel like I’m being led around by the nose or that I’m listening to a kid’s TV show. Several times I wondered if this game was directed at kindergarteners because of the tone the astronaut was using. Still, I appreciate that the character is voice acted at all- full V.O.’s can be somewhat rare in the genre.

Our astronaut is also very curious about the planet, but is adamant that she’s getting out of there ASAP. Isn’t she an explorer? well, here’s a chance to explore! More than once we also end up relying on her gut feelings, adding to how contrived the short story line feels.

The reveal in Act 5 is pretty cool; I didn’t know what to expect about the fate of the planet, but it wasn’t that. Unfortunately, the end of the game really leaves a lot to be desired. Apparently this game connects to something else the developer has done, but it wasn’t clear that you needed that knowledge ahead of time to make the ending feel exciting. It’s also possible that this game will get a sequel, but if it doesn’t, there are so many unanswered questions created by the ending that it feels incredibly unsatisfying. I did not expect to end this game feeling very sad about the outcome for the astronaut and other environments/creatures/etc, but that’s where I’m at.

Final thing:  the musical sting used in cut scenes is really great! But it gets old fast. A little more variety would have been nice. 

Overall okay. I’d add a half star if I could just to support the work that went into all the art, but I just think the story isn’t tight enough to support the experience this game needed to really make a splash.

I love a good deckbuilder. And this is no exception. But on the final boss of a long, long run, every single boss respawns twice after defeat. So you have to beat them 3x. Every single boss, every single run.

I’d expect a boss to respawn now and then. Classic game mechanic. The surprise frustration now and then is part of the point. But this is a quality of life issue. It doesn’t seem to add anything to the game, there are no extra rewards, just an extra 30 min of tediously beating the same boss, over and over.

Worse if you die right at the end of the last fight, because you’re exhausted and start to phone it in, not because your deck is weak.

There may be some kind of unlock to put a stop to this, but I haven’t found one. It’s addictive up to this point, but I just can’t keep playing. A real shame. I hope they fix this!

I really enjoy this game, the combat and team building is very fun as well as collecting the voidpets themselves. But at a certain point, you’re left at a crossroads between waiting literal days to progress a single floor or reaching into your pockets and buying things from the store. Like say, you run into a boss where your team is at a severe type disadvantage, but you have no Voidpets of a high enough level to fight them, or just flat out don’t have any pets with good typing against the boss. Which leaves you stuck waiting for days to get the required EXP and VM to beat the floor. And you can almost completely forget about getting lucky and hatching something with good typing against the boss. The later in the game you get the stingier they are with eggs, to the point where you’ll be lucky to get 3-5 eggs a week. 

Personally, I think this can be solved by just adding more features that give rewards in the game. Whether that be something like a PVP Arena, or an infinite mode where you fight monsters in waves, there just needs to be more ways to get EXP, VM, and Eggs other than just buying them from the shop.

;TLDR; - You hit a point where your only options are buy things from the in game store or wait literal days to progress a single floor.
